Seniors Make Changes
In June Week
Both the Hullabaloo and June
Week were discussed at the senior
class meeting last Tuesday. Dalsemer said that the making of plates
for this year's Hullabaloo would
start immediately. No senior pictures or write-ups will go in unless
some class dues are paid. By.tomorrow all seniors must pay at least
part of their dues, if not the entire
assessment. And by April 15, positively, all dues must be paid in full.
Kaufman, senior treasurer, is in
charge of collecting thc dues and
reporting to the Hullabaloo those
men who do not pay by tomorrw.
Max Armor, chairman of the
June Week Committee, announced
several new plans, which were
voted on. Formerly there have
been two Dormitory dances during
June Week,one of them designated
as the last Cotillon. But because of
the cost of constructing the platform in front of the dormitory,
and of the dangers of inclement
weather, two changes will be made.
Instead of the regular Dormitory
dance there will be a boat ride down
the bay, and instead of the Cotillon
being at the dormitory, it will probably be at the Maryland Casualty.
The vote in the senior class was
greatly in favor of the changes.

One Graduate Student and

One graduate student at Hopkins
and four former Hopkins graduate
students have been awarded fellowships for the coming year by the
trustees of the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation,
which annually, makes awards to
seventy-five- American scholars, scientists and artists who have shown
unusual ability in research and creative ability in the fine arts.

fellowships they will spend all or
part of the coming year in study
and research abroad.

fellowships were Louis Booker
Wright, instructor of English, University of California, and Johnston

physiology, University of Virginia;
and Dr. Roy James Kennedy, research associate in physics, California Institute of Technology.

"'The Champion'. is a three-act

announced on the eve of his annual

Thomas' comedy of "The. Champion." Tonight the Hopkins Barnstormers are primed to give a Baltimore audience the best interpretation of pure comedy thye will ever
witness.

critics to be the best performance

has -imbibed the spirit •: 9f "The

Desch, veteran female, impersonator
of five Barnstormer, productions,
has returned to impersonate Mary,
the little, effervescent, sparkling sister of the champion. A,most-touching scene between mother and
daughter naturally is in. order—
when Mary can suppress her youthful enthusiasm.
Dwight Horne, the heroine,
quickly seems to lose her stiff, English aloOfness when the Lightweight
Champion of the World, with the
light heart and heavy line, enters
with "Benny" Boynton, alias "Gunboat Williams" in the role, and
takes the sedate English household
by storm.

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Although I am not a member of
the junior Class, I certainly want to
congratulate them on their ability
to do things. In their freshman
year they devised the plan of sailing
down the bay, thereby eluding their
would-be captors, and, in fact, even
carried several sophomores as hostages to witness their triumph.
As sophomores they showed Annapolis that there was such a thing
as an undergraduate school at Hopkins, that there was a sophomore
class in existence, and a hot One.
The fortitude exhibited by standing
in the rain for several hours; the
very ferocity with which they attacked the banquet hail; even
though one might call these things
-rowdyism ; their courageousness
cannot be denied.
And in their junior year they had
a Pow-Wow (and how). Some
more sober-minded person may call
it a.drunken brawl, but if he had
attended, if he had as a source of
information his own personal experience, his ideas on the subject
might be entirely changed. The
party was marked by a conspicuous
effort • to make the dance a success,
an effort .to make it an enjoyable,
unforgettable evening. And this
is what a Junior Dance should be.
In all their enterprises the keynote is spirit, class-spirit, schoolspirit. This is the attitude that is
predominant in the junior class, and
it is always welcome to a Hopkins
man—an evidence of spirit. Sometimes they may go to excess in exercising this spirit, but they are in-variably willing to pay promptly
for their mistakes.
The junior class of '29 is undoubtedly one of the best since
1923, and as Hopkins adherents we
should hope for more classes like
it in the future.
Yours,

Seniors Make Changes

Both the Hullabaloo and June
Week were discussed at the senior
class meeting last Tuesday. Dalsemer said that the making of plates
for this year's Hullabaloo would
start immediately. No senior pictures or write-ups will go in unless
some class dues are paid. By.tomorrow all seniors must pay at least

assessment. And by April 15, positively, all dues must be paid in full.

charge of collecting thc dues and
reporting to the Hullabaloo those
men who do not pay by tomorrw.
Max Armor, chairman of the
June Week Committee, announced
several new plans, which were
voted on. Formerly there have
been two Dormitory dances during
June Week,one of them designated
as the last Cotillon. But because of
the cost of constructing the platform in front of the dormitory,
and of the dangers of inclement
weather, two changes will be made.

dance there will be a boat ride down
the bay, and instead of the Cotillon
being at the dormitory, it will probably be at the Maryland Casualty.
The vote in the senior class was
greatly in favor of the changes.

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir:
Although I am not a member of
the junior Class, I certainly want to
congratulate them on their ability
to do things. In their freshman
year they devised the plan of sailing
down the bay, thereby eluding their
would-be captors, and, in fact, even
carried several sophomores as hostages to witness their triumph.
As sophomores they showed Annapolis that there was such a thing
as an undergraduate school at Hopkins, that there was a sophomore
class in existence, and a hot One.
The fortitude exhibited by standing
in the rain for several hours; the
very ferocity with which they attacked the banquet hail; even
though one might call these things
-rowdyism ; their courageousness
cannot be denied.
And in their junior year they had
a Pow-Wow (and how). Some
more sober-minded person may call
it a.drunken brawl, but if he had
attended, if he had as a source of
information his own personal experience, his ideas on the subject
might be entirely changed. The
party was marked by a conspicuous
effort • to make the dance a success,
an effort .to make it an enjoyable,
unforgettable evening. And this
is what a Junior Dance should be.
In all their enterprises the keynote is spirit, class-spirit, schoolspirit. This is the attitude that is
predominant in the junior class, and
it is always welcome to a Hopkins
man—an evidence of spirit. Sometimes they may go to excess in exercising this spirit, but they are in-variably willing to pay promptly
for their mistakes.
The junior class of '29 is undoubtedly one of the best since
1923, and as Hopkins adherents we
should hope for more classes like
it in the future.
Yours,
